Hi. I'm a Hispanic college student, and I wanted to talk about what's been weighing on me. Hello. I've been feeling a little happy and unhappy and sometimes tired, especially since three months, and I've been working from 8:30 to 8 p.m., almost 11 hours a day. I can sometimes work around 7 and work late in the morning. This is going to last about a week every two months. I feel a little tired, which makes me a little anxious.
Well, how do you think about this? Can we talk more?

Because it has become more and more evident recently, especially since I think that I have to work on Saturdays, but I often work on Sundays, sometimes on a day-to-day basis, but not knowing what to do. I have only two classmates in this city, with no family, no amateurs, and I feel like working, but sometimes I want to learn software at night, but I feel that I'm too tired to work a day. And I'm an assistant, and I often watch designers, and I always wonder what to do with similar problems if I'm a designer

You sound tired of the current rhythm of work and life, and the lack of support systems and social activities makes you particularly anxious. Can you tell me more about how you cope with these pressures?

Oh, I'm sorry, I may not be very clear. I didn't mention games and social practices, but I just spoke about my work. But I did participate in some electronic design competitions and social practices in my student age, which have allowed me to accumulate some experience, but I feel a little tired now in the face of the pressure and rhythm of work. I remember those games, though busy, but very productive, and now it seems that there is a lot of work to do, rather than a lot.

You mentioned that the competitions and social practices of the past, while busy, have made you feel very successful, and that the work is busy but not very productive, right? Does this give you some confusion and uncertainty about future career development?

Yes, work and self-learning programmes are parallel, but often result in work taking up most of the time and energy, and leaving me no longer enough time and energy to effectively learn new skills. It makes it hard for me to make progress, and it takes a lot of my energy to do it, and it causes me to be bored and anxious about life.
I understand how you feel, and what you're facing is really getting tired and anxious. Can you say more about what you think changes might help you in your current situation?

At school, the main purpose of the competition and social practice was to gain experience, enhance their abilities, and to be able to get a little more bright on their resumes. But now that we're working, it's not that easy to find out, and even with some experience in the past, we still feel stressed about new jobs and new environments. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”

I heard you say that in the new working environment, you feel that your past experience is not enough to meet the challenges of the present, which puts you under stress. We can continue to explore how to manage these challenges effectively and find some ways to ease the pressure.

Sorry to get you wrong, I didn't do the electronic design competition at work. And, at the moment, the pressure at work has prevented me from engaging as actively as I did in extra activities. I haven't adapted to the rhythm and stress here, and I'm stuck between busy and tired, and I can't find a clear direction.
You mentioned social practice. Have you been designated as some of the responsible actors? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.

In my work, I am not really the head of the office, but an assistant. But sometimes the leadership will let me take on a few small tasks, probably because the leadership expects me to do it more. It also gives me some motivation, but it also feels more pressure. If I fail to meet the leadership's expectations, I fear that my career will be compromised. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.
I see. You're struggling with tasks on multiple projects, aren't you? Is there anything in this that you're particularly worried or troubled about?

Of course, I fear that I am now very hard at basic work, and that I have no extra energy to learn additional skills or to participate in competitions and social practices. If this continues, I fear that my career will be stalled and even affect my physical and mental health.

Are you sure you have a lot of tasks, and sometimes you don't have a clear schedule, and you work a lot of confusion and hard work? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.

I am not actually in charge, but I do have to help with a lot of things. When things pile up, they feel like flies, and many things are confused, and long hours of work make me feel particularly tired, like I'm working, but I don't see results, and I'm confused.
You mentioned the headless fly crashing. This confusion makes you very uncomfortable, right?

Yes, especially when things get a little bit messy and I don't know what to do first. And sometimes leadership demands are unclear, making me even more difficult. For a long time, I feel like I'm really going to crash, having no sense of direction, no sense of work, no sense of achievement.
This confusion and incompatibilities are really hard. What do you think the biggest source of stress is when you deal with these things?

Well, sometimes it feels desperate. Feels like you're paying off, and seeing designers deal with things makes me worry about how well I can do what I do. Feel like I'm wasting my time and energy, not growing, and I'm particularly anxious.
Now come back and see why you think you're doing all this?

At first, I was trying to build up my experience and enhance my abilities, but now I feel that I have not been given the necessary boost in doing these things, but that I am bored with day after day. This has led me to question whether my choices and efforts are worth it.
I can understand how you feel. What part of the job do you think makes you feel so tired?

I don't get to meet specific people at work. For colleagues and clients in general, I sometimes find it difficult to communicate, especially when stress is high, and I don't know how to handle these relationships better.
The difficulty of communication does add to the pressure. What do you think you need in this case?

Sorry, my work does not involve social practice and children of special groups, which may have been a misleading message. But, I have had some experience of volunteer work that makes me feel good about helping people and doing something meaningful, but the work that I do now leaves me with no time to do it.
You know, volunteer experience sounds like a lot to you, right?

I used to help organize intellectual activities like hand-made, simple science experiments or team games. These activities, though simple but interesting, are still reminiscent of them. That may be why I feel more stress and boredom at work.
Those events do sound reminiscent. Do you think you'll find some of these pleasures outside your work?

It's interesting, but I've never done it at work. This is what I do at school or after school. In my work, I'm faced with very specific tasks, with little flexibility and creative space. So sometimes I think that if I could do something like this, I might feel more than I do.
What do you expect?

I look forward to finding a balance between a sense of advancement and accomplishment at work, and a space and time to do what is of interest to me and to develop new skills. Better working environments and support systems, or more friends and social circles, could make my life more meaningful and enriching. Sometimes I feel like I have to represent my community on campus, which adds stress.
Does the balance you have mentioned sound important, and could you be more specific about the main difficulties you are currently experiencing in your work?

I'm not actually actually doing this kind of activity or project right now, and I'm trying to focus on the confusion of work and how to balance work and life. If we can find a more appropriate pace and approach to work, maybe it will make my life more productive and meaningful. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.
I see. It is really crucial to find a way of working that makes you feel rich and productive. Have you tried some methods or ideas?

Thank you, and this advice has made me realize that perhaps I can try to find some small challenges or interesting projects in my work, with a learning and exploring attitude. That might make my job less boring and bring back some sense of achievement. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.
This sounds like a good attempt, and looks forward to hearing more about your exploration and experience sharing. Today may be close. Can we continue our exploration next time?
Okay, thanks for the time and advice. See you next week. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
See you next week.

Hi. I'm a Hispanic college student, and I wanted to talk about what's been weighing on me. Hello, I feel like I've been in a state of chaos lately, like struggling in the mud, not knowing how to get out.
Hello, sounds like you're really struggling with your situation. I wonder when you're starting to feel that way.

I've been in a bad situation since I dropped out two years ago. I feel like I'm nothing and I don't know what it means to exist. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.
Sounds like dropping out two years ago had a deep impact on you. Would you like to talk to me more about this experience?
Yes, that decision has a lot to do with me. It's like a deserter who doesn't go through school in the face of the situation.
I see. You think you've been like a deserter since you dropped out. That's what's bothering you, right?
Yes, I feel like I haven't really put it down. I feel sorry for my parents, they've invested so much in my studies, and I'm giving up.
It sounds like you feel guilty about your parents, and you feel guilty about your decision. I understand that it makes you feel bad.

Yeah, and I've been doing nothing for years at home. I feel like I'm being left behind when I see my peers graduate and get a job. Sometimes I feel like I have to represent my community on campus, which adds stress.

When you see your peers graduating and finding a job, you feel left behind a lot. This must make you feel helpless and anxious, right? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
I've been doing nothing for more than a year, and I've been at home, sometimes working as a job, but I can't hold it for long, and I feel like I'm not motivated or in a way.
Well, it sounds like you've been through a lot of trouble and some confusion for over a year.
Yes, I feel very anxious to see people around me moving forward one step at a time.
Do you think that anxiety is more of a result of comparison with your peers?
I... I feel ashamed to talk to my brothers sometimes, like, to my brothers who are very close, who talk about work.
I understand. Can you tell me what makes you feel ashamed?
Yes, because they all found a good job, and I didn't do anything and felt like I was particularly failed.
Does it sound like you're frustrated by the current situation or feel a little pressure on them?

Yes, they sometimes complain to me about the stress of work, and I don't even have the capital to complain because I haven't even found a stable job. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
This may make you feel like you're being left behind in some way, right? You want to be able to make some progress, and you don't feel left behind.

Yes, I wish I could make progress, and I don't want to be like this anymore. But it's a bit of a breakdown when I think of starting to get a job. Sometimes I feel like I have to represent my community on campus, which adds stress.
When did this break-up happen?

Especially at night, when a person thinks about the future, he feels no hope and sometimes even wonders whether it would be better if he had not dropped out of school. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
Sounds like that drop-out has had a lot on you. Would you like to talk to me about what happened?
Yes, it was like a shadow that was always over me. Every time my brother mentioned their work, I felt like I was wrong. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.
It sounds like these memories make you feel like you're struggling. Admit that you're unhappy, what does that mean?
It's like admitting that you're failing. I don't want to be that kind of person, but I can't find a way to make myself happy.
These emotions seem to be a long backlog in your mind. How do you think they affect you? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yes, I always tell myself that to get up like this, it's often temporary and quickly get into negative emotions.
How does it affect you to tell yourself that it's not good?
That is, time should not be wasted on grief, on facing life positively, on trying to find work, but always on the job.

Sometimes emotional expression is necessary, and your anxiety is a real response to the situation. You want to get back to it quickly, right? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yes, I hope I will get better immediately, not to let my family and friends worry about me, not to stop in this state.
You fear that the situation will cause anxiety among your family, especially your parents, who have already been worried a lot about you.
Yes, I know it takes time, but it's always felt like it was getting farther away from the target and more anxious.

I understand your anxiety and see that you're already trying to get help, and this is a very important step. Likewise, everyone lives at different paces, and you chose to drop out of school, and it must be a deliberate decision.
And that is true, I think that the drop-out was my best choice. I need some time to adjust myself, and I am still struggling, but at least I am already facing the problem.

Everyone has their own rhythm, and it is important to follow the true feeling in your heart, and the choice was a sign of your responsibility. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Well, I understand. I should listen to my heart more and not always try to meet the expectations of others.
If you feel sad, don't force yourself to say "let it go" and be happy. Everyone has the right to be sad. But we know that after grief, we will still go forward.
Thank you. I'll try to accept my emotions, not to suppress them, and hopefully find my way.
I hope your emotions will be alleviated.
Well, I feel better, thanks for your help. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
You can contact me again if you feel anxious.
Okay, I will.
We can change slowly, not to put too much pressure on ourselves. If you want to consult, you can make an appointment in advance.
Thank you, then we'll see you next time. It's better after 16 p.m.
You're welcome. I'll see you here today.

Because he never had any sign of love, I'm not sure he meant anything to me. But he talked to me a long time yesterday at the end of the night and apologized that he suddenly failed to reply because something was wrong.

He just keeps talking to me about relationships, love, and so on, but he's not gonna get away from me.

He did not show possession, but he was a very common friend exchange.

Yeah, he probably wouldn't dare to say it.

Yes, I want to understand and accommodate his concerns, but I hope that there will be some progress. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.

Do you think you understand his fears well? How does that evasiveness and fear make you feel? What do you think you have in this relationship? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yeah, I know he may have been worried, but I'm confused and tired of having to do this.

I didn't tell him directly, just by taking a little care of him to know I cared about him.

Yes, I really want him to know what I'm thinking.

Yeah, but I don't know if he felt it.
Maybe try to understand his current state. He may not hate being close to you.
Well, I understand that he may have his own concerns and considerations.
Yeah, he may have a lot of worries and fears. And your efforts may be close to him because you're looking at this. But sometimes we need to find a more appropriate way.
Well, I'll try to say it, hopefully, to make him understand my feelings.
You can try to be supportive of him, express your feelings and give him some space. If he still finds it difficult, you can calm down, but let him know that you'll be around him when he needs it.
Well, I'll try to say it, hopefully, to make him understand my feelings.
Can the middle give him their best wishes and care in due course, and maintain a proper link?
Okay, I'll take care of him in due course and not let him feel too far away. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
Well, you can call or type, depending on your feelings, which way you can communicate better.
Well, I'll think about calling, so it's more direct.
It's a course of action. How do you think it works?
I'm curious. What would he think if I didn't call him these days?
You're afraid he'll have some negative reading of your behavior, right?
He probably thinks I'm losing interest in him. Does he worry?
It's possible, but what do you think that guess will do to your relationship?
But if I look for him, he may also think I'm a little anxious and not know what he thinks.
Sounds like you're having a lot of uncertainty about his reaction. It bothers you, doesn't it?
I think it's time to care about him, not to make him feel cold or hot.
It's a balanced strategy that might help your relationship. What do you think you should do?

You're welcome. Can I fill out the volume?
Yes, no problem.
