Hi. I'm a Hispanic college student, and I wanted to talk about what's been weighing on me. Hello, teacher. Long time no see.
- Mm-hmm. How are you?
The same is true in recent times, with a particularly busy day and a very busy day.
Does it sound like you're going to be working hard. Did you get any pressure on you as the class grows?
I sometimes feel like I've been doing something or dreamt it, but it's just a delusion, it's weird.
This sounds a little disturbing to you. Can you tell me more about your feelings and thoughts?
I feel anxious, anxious, sometimes a little scared. The dream scene is vague, probably the classroom or the exam.
These vague dreams and anxiety coexist, seem to give you a lot of negative emotions. Can you describe in detail how these scenes feel?
I feel anxious, anxious, sometimes a little scared. The dream scene is vague, probably the classroom or the exam.
You mean the new school classroom?
Yes, the new school classroom. It's a strange and familiar feeling, and sometimes it's like you've had a dream before.
What impact does that have on your life?
This is a disturbing feeling and a discomfort to my learning, because it is always distracting and strange.
Does it affect your learning and life?
Well, yeah. I was always distracted during class and then I realized that the teacher said nothing.
Sounds like you've been having a lot of trouble at school. How long will this feeling of anxiety and fear last?
Usually, it lasts all night, sometimes even the next morning.
What's the specific thing that makes you uncomfortable and scared? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Thinking of how badly I was at the exam and feeling that I couldn't help myself. I was afraid I wouldn't keep up with the pace and let my parents down.
I understand that pressure in the exam is really stressful. Have you tried to share it with anyone around you?
Cousin said she had a similar feeling before, and she said that it might be a stressful situation and asked me to relax.
How would you react when you heard your cousin say that?
There is some comfort, but the reality is making it difficult for me to relax, and it is felt that my cousin may not fully understand my situation.
Yeah, I understand. If someone else feels the same, will it make you feel better? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yeah, knowing that people have felt that way, they'll feel less strange.
It reminds me that many people have similar emotional experiences. Knowing that they're not the only ones with such experiences can bring some comfort, right?
Really? That's good. Otherwise I thought I was alone.
You're not the only one. Does it help to know that someone else has a similar experience?
In that case, I feel that I am not the only one with such problems, that the problem may not be that serious, or that I am confused.
I understand. Confusion is a normal feeling. Do you think about it a lot lately? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yes, especially when moods are low or stress is particularly high, it comes to mind.
Well, I understand. What do these memories bring you in these moments?
It was difficult to calm down and to think about it all the time, and doing something else would be affected.
Can you say more about what you're thinking? Or what's bothering you?
Because I try to keep myself out of this, to keep myself busy, but sometimes I can't help it.
Well, it's really hard to control. So, how do you feel about the new school environment?
The new school is much worse than I thought, it's not the same atmosphere as I thought, and it feels a lot more stressful.
I understand, it does sound stressful. Is there anything else that makes you feel uncomfortable?
There is only one day of leave per week and all other time is spent in school.
I see, it feels like the timing is really tight. So what's the difference between what you think?
I'm not well, my stomach is not well. I'm not well, teachers are too tough. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
You're not feeling well? Yeah, so we can see how you can ease your stomach. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yeah, mostly the stomach. It hurts more when you're nervous.
What do you think caused your stress?
People are the main ones, and everyone is fighting for you to die and for me to live without a good supporting environment.
I understand, it's a matter of human relationships that makes you nervous. Can you tell us more about this?
Some of the students are not reasonable, they like to be smart. They don't take care of people's feelings.
These things make you uncomfortable and uncomfortable, don't they?

There are some better friends, but most people are cold. Everyone has a clear goal and it's hard to get in touch. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.
It sounds like you're not very well-off in the social setting of school. Is there anything else that makes you uncomfortable with relationships?
Well, there's also schools that aren't as good as they thought.
What impact does the school environment and facilities have on your life and learning?
The teaching buildings are old and the dormitory is very poor and not comfortable. But they can only be adapted as much as possible.
There is indeed some dissatisfaction with the construction facilities.
Yes, the dormitories and classrooms are common.
What about the class? How's it going?
The curriculum is very intensive, full of daily time and no free time to rest. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.
Does it feel a little stress?
Not much, but we have to try to adapt or we'll drop out of the curriculum.
It's not easy. Is the teacher demanding you?
Teachers are harsh, especially class teachers, with no flexibility and are rigid.
How's it going with the kids in this situation? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Some people do not attend classes and discipline in the classes is not good, which affects the enthusiasm of some.
What do you think people do when they don't take classes? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Some people play cell phones during school hours or speak without paying any attention to what the teacher is saying.
Why do you think everyone doesn't take classes?
It may be because it feels too tight and has already taken too much effort.
Does this affect you?
Yeah, Dad always reminds me to try and learn, not to be distracted, but I'm under a lot of pressure.
What's your dad's attitude towards your studies?
Yeah, he thinks I'm under a lot of pressure, and he wants me to relax, but I can't relax.
How do you understand the pressure you feel?
There are some reasons, but more so the pressure from the school, the expectations of the teacher and the expectations of the family.
It sounds like these expectations and pressures are really bothering you. What do you think of them?
I want to go to high school and continue to be better educated and not disappoint my parents.
Do you think these pressures and expectations are what you want or more to keep them from being disappointed?
I don't want to be criticized by teachers, nor let my grades fall, fearing shame. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.
I understand that it is hard to feel that you don't want to be criticized, and what do you think that fear and pressure are coming from?
Yeah, especially if I don't like being criticized, it makes me feel bad.
Sounds like you're particularly sensitive to criticism, especially from teachers, which makes you feel bad enough, right?
It's mostly because they don't like to be criticized by teachers, they feel useless and they hurt their self-esteem.
Well, I understand that teacher criticism is a setback to your self-esteem, and that is a really heavy feeling. Have you ever had a particularly unhappy experience of being criticized?
If it were a classmate, it would be less serious, but I would be particularly nervous and depressed if the teacher criticized.
Are you scared too?
Yes, afraid of teachers who think about me differently, and of people who are not working. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
Mm-hmm, that's normal. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
It is a paradox that you have always wanted to work but felt unable to achieve your goals.
Why pretend not to be afraid?
I'm afraid I'll be under the impression that I can't bear the pressure.
Well, I get it. You want to look stronger, don't you?
Yes, I pretended to be calm, but I was really scared and anxious.
You're trying to make yourself look easy, but you still feel a lot of burden inside, aren't you?
Well, he was taken, but nothing happened, just stood up to the Convention. He felt a little overstretched. Sometimes I feel like I have to represent my community on campus, which adds stress.
Did you ask him what happened? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
He was asked, and he was punished for listening to the school convention and then he came back.
Oh, did he mention anything else?
Yes, they had him copy the Convention several times, and as a punishment, it was no big deal. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
Do you know what he got punished for?
He was punished for violating some school rules. It was just because he was taken away.
I see. You were surprised, weren't you?
Yeah, he yelled, and we were all so scared. Sometimes I feel like I have to represent my community on campus, which adds stress.
Sounds like an impressive experience. What do you think that's gonna do to you?
I feel that the school system is strict and sometimes there is some fear, but it is not really that scary.
What are the main reasons for your fear?
A little scared, but I didn't have the courage to go to the fifth floor, and I felt like there was something really nasty going on there.
You just mentioned something strange. Can you say a little more?
People say there's something weird that feels like something bad is hidden on the fifth floor.
Sounds like everyone's worried about the fifth floor.
Yeah, no one dares to go up there. Legends say there's a ghost, but I don't believe it, but I'm afraid.
Where did you hear that information?
It was heard from the senior sister who said that something bad had happened on the fifth floor, but it was not clear what the exact circumstances were.
You're upset about these rumors, aren't you?
Yeah, they didn't seem to have any bad effect on their return, just a little bit of trouble.
What's the main thing you're worried about?
I'm afraid it's gonna be a lot of trouble, getting called to the Convention, remember?
It sounds really annoying.
Yeah, but I'm still nervous.
I understand that the face of unknown things is always tense.
Yes, because I don't know what's going to happen, I don't know. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.
Do you need to relax yourself to deal with these things?
Yes, there are things in school that are not drugged, and they are hard to face.
And with all this, you feel the pressure and the discomfort, right?
Sometimes it's disgusting, but I have to face it. I really don't know what to do.
It's uncomfortable, isn't it? Can you tell us what it is?
Well, it's just really hard, but I can't stand it for grades.
I understand that this is really a very painful situation. Can you tell me when it started?
Yes, the father did, and he was patient, and no matter how hard he was, he didn't complain.
Sounds like you respect your father very much. He's your model in many ways, right?
Yes, often stomach pains, especially when stress is high, affect the food. Sometimes I feel like I have to represent my community on campus, which adds stress.
Do you think stomach pain has a direct bearing on your usual stress?
Me too. I can't even eat when my stomach is so swollen.
It sounds like it really has a lot to do with your life. Let's see how we can allay this discomfort, okay?
Sometimes it's felt like an invisible pressure, and I can't breathe.
Know what it means to know your father is like your experience?
I feel like I'm not alone, and knowing that my father has been through this, makes me feel like I should be able to hold on.
Well, I see that the father's experience is really very supportive of you. We're almost there today. Anything else we can add? Can we stop here?
Well, it's late for today. Nothing to add. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.
Okay, we'll go first. If you need anything, we can talk about it. What's your usual convenience?
I'm off for one day a week, and I have to go back tomorrow. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
I see. We can adjust it to your time. Can we please make another date on the micro-letter?
Well, I think we can talk about it at some other time if we have time.
Okay, we'll keep in touch. We'll have a date on the mail.
Yes, and we can be very easy to communicate with.
Tomorrow's Monday, I'm full here.
Okay, let's make a date.
Okay, well, let's make a good time. I'll call you later to confirm the details. Have a nice weekend. Bye. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.

Hi. I'm a Hispanic college student, and I wanted to talk about what's been weighing on me. Hello, teacher, it's been really bad lately.

I don't know if I'm really sure that my mom is all for me to go abroad, except that she's always worried about my ability to live independently. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
Sounds like Mom is supporting you abroad, but she has some concerns about your ability to live independently, and how does she specifically express those concerns?

She always asked me how I was going to do, and she sometimes mentioned the challenges of leaving the country. She would insist on me learning to cook with relatives, to do chores, and to go to the neighborhoods of the university early to adapt. Although these were good suggestions, she kept mentioning that I felt particularly stressed. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.

I usually just get a little bit of a prank or a little complaining. A face-to-face conflict with her only makes me more restless, sometimes pretending to be good enough to continue with my homework.
Well, you've been complaining and grumpy about it. Have you ever talked to Mom about why Mom's so anxious?

Maybe she's too worried that I'm not going to fit, but I don't really know how to talk to her. It's always like it's getting a little bit tense. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.
I think Mom must have her reasons, or what good is she always staring at you? Does Mom keep an eye on you about your car, or is she always pushing you, pushing you?
Not just the car, she's been looking at me in all my aspects of my life. She seems to be worried about every detail.

Well, I heard you say your mother's concern for you is a little stressful. Maybe you could try to understand her concerns and then see if there's a good time to talk to her about your feelings, take it slow, not necessarily solve things in a minute.
It sounds like a good point. I'm just worried that saying it might make us even more nervous. I know she's doing it for my own good, but it's hard to bear her concern.

Well, I understand your concern. It's normal. You can express your feelings in a gentle way at the right time. Maybe you can start with small things and build a smoother way of communicating. What do you think?
I think it might be useful to try talking to Mom, if you're listening to me.
Yeah, you've actually taken the first step and dared to face your feelings and challenges. Remember, whatever the difficulties, we can talk about them.
It's really hard. I feel trapped in this period, and I'm in a difficult situation. I know I want to be independent, to face the future, but there's a lot of uncertainty and fear.
Uh-huh. Can I say something?

I feel heavy every time I think of going abroad. Especially when I see negative comments and news, I wonder if I can hold it. I've always wanted to pursue dreams, but now I feel like I'm moving on to an unknown and potentially painful future.
It sounds like you're under a lot of pressure, and these voices make you feel scared and suspicious. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.

Well, it's really sad. Every time you think about leaving your house to face a completely alien environment, you have a feeling of incompetence and loneliness. I'm afraid that when I get there, I can't adjust, or even collapse.
I can feel your uncertainty and loneliness about the future. These fears and fears are real.
I feel a little bit of crying right now, but I feel like crying is useless. The difficulty is still there, and it won't disappear because of tears.
Your feelings are real, and it's important to allow yourself to have such feelings.
Well, I'll try to face my emotions, not hold them all the time. Maybe I need to release them.
Yes, giving yourself some time to face and express your emotions is also a manifestation of strength.
Thank you, teacher. It's easier to say it, and it gives me some courage to face the confusion and the fear.
If it's sad, imagine I'm with you, filming your back until you feel better, and we're here today, and we'll continue next week.
Okay, teacher. I hope we have some new developments next week. Thank you for your time today.
Okay, I hope you feel better. Sleep tonight. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.

Dad's not really having any mental problems. I'm sorry I didn't explain it. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.

It's actually my bipolar emotional disorder, and the re-emergence of depression due to bullying in schools. Afraid of a breakdown under high stress.

The fear of heights has also affected many aspects, such as work that requires high-altitude work, and I can't do it at all.

Well, this story you told me today, I read a lot of your hidden feelings, whether of fear of your father, anger, hesitation, fear, shame in reporting, mistrust of the police, anger, and the ease and comfort of the final appeal, are all the feelings you've really experienced. I believe you have a lot of other experiences that are hidden behind your mind, so painful and terrible that you may have chosen to suppress them for a number of times, so that you can stop experiencing them and make yourself feel no longer.
Yes, it feels like it's always depressing, afraid that it's going to make things worse.

Well, yes, there are similar feelings in many experiences, and similar processes of retreat or transformation. Today is our time. Would you like to continue with this topic next time? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
I think Tuesday night at 10:00 should be fine. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
Okay, so we'll continue our conversation on Tuesday at 10:00 p.m. Thank you for sharing today. Bye!
Okay, thank you. See you Tuesday at 10:00.
Okay, I've got a reservation for you for Tuesday night at 10:00. See you next week.
I see. Good night.
Good night.

I do have plans for continuing the exam, but I feel stressed out every time and I'm not motivated to study.
When are you going to take the exam again?

It has not yet been decided and consideration may be given to waiting a little longer to adjust the mindset before registering. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.

Well, I think there's a detailed learning plan that can help me a lot.

Well, it does make a better allocation of time, and I'll try that. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
With a clear plan, you might feel more control and ease some pressure.

I am, in fact, a little worried because I have been dealing with a complex relationship and my emotions have been affected. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.

Something happened between me and a friend, and I had a little bit of a mistrust, which was confusing and troubling. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.
I can tell you're angry about this. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yeah, I'm confused about the information he sent me. I don't know what he meant.

It is primarily my feeling that I have been exploited and that some of my actions and decisions have made me feel disrespectful.

I always felt that he was not really on my side, that he was always in his way of controlling and arranging, and that if I objected, he would be angry. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
It sounds really sad. You want him to respect your mind more, don't you?
Yes, I'm really upset, I feel like I'm being used as a tool, and I feel hurt.
I can feel your pain and sadness. Your feelings are important.
I try to understand his intentions, but I am really confused and confused about how to deal with this relationship.
Sounds like this relationship is bothering you, and we can go on to the next meeting. See you Wednesday.

You are a virtual counseling supervisor roleplay.
Counselor: warm, client-centered, trauma-informed, uses MI + CBT skills.

Hi. I'm a Hispanic college student, and I wanted to talk about what's been weighing on me. Hello.
Hello, nice to meet you.
Okay, thanks. Sometimes I feel like I have to represent my community on campus, which adds stress.
Thank you for your trust. Anything you want to talk to me about? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Well, I've been trying to get a psychological consultation, but I just don't know how to talk. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
It's okay. Take your time. You can start whenever you're ready. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
I feel really bad, but I'm really bad lately.
I'm sorry to hear about your recent troubles. Can you share with me the details?
Well, okay. Where do I start? A lot of things have been in my heart for a long time.
You can start with what you think is most necessary. Anything you feel important can tell me, and I'll listen.
Some things in the family, some things that were long ago, I was afraid to tell people I knew, fearing ignorance or ridicule.
I can understand how you feel. It's really hard to deal with.
My parents always wanted to maintain a decent image of the family, so let me look at it. Our family is not that good.
Sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure inside the family, which must be bothering you.
Thank you. Sometimes I feel lonely and I can't find someone who can really talk.
It is very painful for you to feel alone and not find someone who can understand you. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yeah, I understand. I really don't know how to express my pain.
I understand, it's not easy. Should we try to start with a specific experience?
Well, I didn't mention entrepreneurs. I was a student, and I was in a bad state at school. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
Sorry, I may have misheard. You said you were in bad shape at school. Let's talk about this. Did you have any problems at school?

Yes, I really want to be recognized, but the current state makes it difficult for me to concentrate on learning, to be insomnia and to influence my studies. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
I feel your fatigue and pain, cry and hug. I see you never answer. I wonder if you're out of line.
Sorry, because it's boring to think about, sometimes sweating and even fainting. It's not a problem to go to the hospital, but I know it's not a physical problem.
Well, I'm listening. You mentioned insomnia and difficulty in concentrating. These issues have a lot to do with you. Can we talk about them more specifically?
Not work, not school. I'm worried about my future, I don't see hope, I'm always in a bad mood.

Well, I understand, it's about the pressure on school. You mention the fear of the future, you don't see hope. What kind of pressure is it? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Thank you, I'm really scared I can't get out of this, and I feel like I'm falling into a black hole.
I understand how you feel, and this is really scary. You can share this with me. I'm touched. Let's see what we can do to help you alleviate this feeling, okay?
But I don't feel strong, I feel weak and I'm dying to face these difficulties.
I can see the pain and the helplessness in your heart, but it's a strong and courageous way of coming here to ask for help. Let's find a way to make you feel less alone and powerless, okay?
Thank you for your encouragement. I just... really need a little help, even if you tell me how to start, or teach me some way to ease things.
It's really hard to hear, you're really brave. We can work out and find a way for you together. But we're almost there today.
Okay, thank you. We'll talk about it another time.
Okay, you're welcome. I look forward to our next dialogue and wish you a quiet night.

You are a virtual counseling supervisor roleplay.
Counselor: warm, client-centered, trauma-informed, uses MI + CBT skills.
Client: a Hispanic college/graduate student in the U.S. (may be first-gen). Bilingual/bicultural context may matter.
Goal: practice counseling micro-skills (empathy, reflection, validation, open questions) and cultural responsiveness.

Hi. I'm a Hispanic college student, and I wanted to talk about what's been weighing on me. Hello, Tiny. I've been wondering why I have so many strange behaviors and ideas. I feel different from others, a little afraid that people will think I'm insane.
Sounds like you're a lot confused about your behavior and you care about what people think of you, don't you?
I'm starting to wonder about myself again. Why am I getting so curious, even a little crazy? Why is my focus always somewhere that no one else can see? Am I really different from anyone else?
This curiosity is disturbing you. Can you tell me more about your concerns? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.

Recently, I found myself in class with a constant lack of concentration, sometimes touching the arm, watching the skin, and even these little things fascinated me. And, suddenly, I wanted to cut a little square, and I tried to make it look like it was. This is happening more and more often, and I don't even care what teachers are saying.
Sounds like these little things are fascinated. You're confused by the fact that you're not focused in class?

Yes, when I was a little girl, teachers and parents said I was smart, but I never studied very well. I was called by teachers from first to sixth grade, because I was always too smart but lazy for all kinds of small things.
How do you feel about the many evaluations you have heard about yourself since elementary school?
Teachers always say I'm smart but not hard, and I can do a great job if I focus. Parents think I have the potential to do better, but they're desperate, because my attention is really too low.
These evaluations seem to have left some impressions in your mind that you have a lot of thought about your performance, and how do you think they have affected you?
This label has a lot to do with me. Teachers and parents always say I'm smart, but I don't know if it's true. I start to wonder if I'm talented or whether I'm wasting my time.
What makes you so suspicious?

Sometimes I feel like I'm not really so smart, but I'm just a little bit of a weird idea and hobby that makes me look different. But when I'm faced with something that requires real brainiac, I often can't concentrate, and I think I'm really not as smart as anyone else thinks I am. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.
Sounds like you have a lot of doubts about your talent and talent.

Yes, if I have no talent, I fear that I will become a normal person, that I will live in peace and that I will be easily ignored or mocked. I always want to show my differences, especially when I'm with my classmates.
I understand that your fear that you are not considered a gifted person may affect your position in the crowd and the perception of you by others.
I'd feel like I'm failing, losing the expectations of parents and teachers, and I'd feel like that. I'm afraid to be seen as a normal, mediocre person.
You're afraid of being seen as a mediocre person, which makes you anxious, right?
Yes, I fear that I will become ordinary. From childhood to age, expectations have been high. I always thought I should be different, ordinary means mediocrity.
That is a very important part of what is expected and what is not.
If I were mediocrity, I felt that my existence was worthless, as if I lost the meaning of life. The expectations of all people for me, or for myself, were all broken.
When do you think this idea of thinking you shouldn't be mediocrity began?
Well, the teacher always said I was smart but didn't try. I started to think that, since I had the potential, I shouldn't be a human being.
The evaluation at that time had a lot to do with you. What do you think that would have had to do with your life?

Some of them sometimes ignore primary school. But in junior high and high school, I always bring me to you in some special way, though sometimes it's exhausting. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.
Well, please give me a detailed account of these experiences.
I was a poor, common and naughty student in elementary school for a while. I was not particularly concerned about me, I felt like a bad student, but I was particularly lonely and without a goal.
That time seems to be important to you. Can you say more?

Yeah, I was not interested in learning, and the teacher thought I didn't want to go up, and the classmates didn't really listen to me, and I was completely ignored. So I wanted to use some special behavior to attract attention.
That experience seems to have had a profound impact on you. Do you think that some of your feelings are related to what happened?

I mean, I'm not highlighting my own speciality, but because I'm not good at grades and performance, and it affects my normal development. Being a normal “bad student” like that makes me feel worthless.
You feel like something special about yourself is buried, right?

When I found out that some of my behaviors were something that could attract attention, I started to think that I was special, like I was the only one who could do that. I liked that feeling, I felt different.
It's important to you to feel that you want to be different, right?
Yes, I've been trying to keep this image, so I can get more recognition. I don't want to be seen as ordinary, but I'm tired of it.
Have you ever thought about what you're going to be?

Sometimes I wonder what kind of scientist I might be in the future or someone who invented it. Because it makes me feel really special, really different. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
Sounds like an idea that exhilarated you, didn't it?
Yes, this fantasy makes me feel really different, and I feel so excited when I think of what I might have achieved in the future.

From your description, it can be seen that you have always wanted to get a sense of identity and existence through your own efforts and uniqueness. But sometimes, when reality does not match that expectation, you may be lost and confused, right?

Yes, I rely on that concept to maintain my identity and happiness, but if reality makes me feel that I am really ordinary, I will become painful, even a little lost and lost. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.
I understand that this feeling is really painful.
I know that I am vulnerable to myself, but I don't know what to do. This denial of my ordinaryness really makes me tired, but I don't know how to get rid of it.
This self-concept puts a lot of pressure on you, and it sounds like you're eager to find new ways to identify yourself.

Yes, sometimes I feel like a building built on sand could collapse at any moment. But I don't know how to change that. Sometimes I feel like I have to represent my community on campus, which adds stress.
Your feelings are understandable and putting the foundations on the ground may make you feel more stable and secure.
Yes, it is. This particular feeling gives me confidence, but it also scares me of losing it.
We can try to explore more aspects to build a more comprehensive and solid self-identification.

I know that, but I don't know how to expand my evaluation system, no longer relying on the “special” point. It's really hard for me to adjust my views. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.
Together, we can find concrete ways to gradually expand your sense of self-identification, so that it will not depend on one aspect alone.

You're right, I'm so dependent on that feeling that I sometimes feel that I've been kidnapped by this expectation. I'm almost used to thinking about how to make myself look different. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
Do you feel that your thoughts, your thoughts, are too monolithic and solid?
Sometimes I realize that, and I feel that many of my ideas are kind of solid, like they're in some kind of pattern and they can't change.
Have you tried to discover and accept some different views and possibilities?
Yes, I always thought that I had to be the most special, and once I found myself less special, I felt very lost and anxious and completely lost in sight of the other possibilities.
This feeling may have its advantages in the short term, but in the long run, have you considered the possible implications?
I am also beginning to realize, as you say, that there are more problems that may arise in the long run. And, I am now feeling some negative effects.
Yes, it could be a good opportunity to observe your everyday thinking patterns.
Yes, I'll try to see my own mindset, see where I'm getting into solid thinking, and try to find some way to change.

If you want, you can record your thoughts and your judgments on something. Then you can look at your thoughts and see what they are. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Well, I would like to try to record and look at my own ideas, which might help me to understand some of my inner patterns and habits.
It's nice to hear you're willing to try. It might help you better understand your inner world.
Yes, hoping to find a healthier and more appropriate way to accommodate yourself. Neither is it in the mediocre fear, nor is it always dependent on “special” to define yourself.
You want to find a balance that can see its particulars and not rely too much on it to define yourself, right?

Yes, a bit of flexibility does not deny its uniqueness completely, nor does it rely entirely on it to define itself. I need a balance. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
Yes, while accepting your own specialities, other diverse self-evaluation systems are being established, which can help you to develop a better and healthy self-awareness.
Thank you, I think it's helpful. I'm going to try to expand my self-evaluation system to make myself more diverse and healthy.
Good. If you need an internal reminder, you can use a sentence like, "When I cross the river, he's my boat, but when I go ashore, I need to leave it."

I will take that as an internal language, and remind myself, when needed, that I will not take the original idea back. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
If you do not want to take it seriously when you are studying in a special course, you can also tell yourself that in your heart, and encourage yourself to look at it with a new perspective.
Well, I will try to use that phrase to encourage myself to face the challenges of learning and life with a new attitude when it is difficult.
Well, your understanding is very helpful to you, and it's good to hear.
Thank you, God, I feel that through this conversation I have some new insights and some ways of responding.
Well, hopefully we can think about some new perspectives. Do you think you need to ask for another consultation? I think we can talk about more.
I think it's helpful for me, and I'm here to relax and to let myself go. Being willing to continue my next consultation will help me to explore and grow in greater depth.
Great. General counseling one or three times a week. I suggest we meet next Monday at 4:00 p.m., do you think it's appropriate?
Yes, it's very appropriate next Monday at 4 p.m., thank you. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.
Okay, see you next week!
Thank you, Tin. See you next week!
Please evaluate this meeting. Thank you.

You are a virtual counseling supervisor roleplay.
Counselor: warm, client-centered, trauma-informed, uses MI + CBT skills.
Client: a Hispanic college/graduate student in the U.S. (may be first-gen). Bilingual/bicultural context may matter.

Hi. I'm a Hispanic college student, and I wanted to talk about what's been weighing on me. Well, it's mostly academic. Especially since we added two subjects, the curriculum has become so tight that it doesn't feel like it's time enough to stay up late and work. Life is good, and sometimes it's too busy to eat.
Sounds like a lot of challenges to school recently. You must have had a hard time facing so many jobs every day.

Yeah, sometimes I feel really stressed out. Not just a lot of work, but a lot of tests and projects. Every time I do a job, a new one comes back, and it feels like I never stop. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.
How much time does it take to write a book every day? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
It takes four to five hours, or even more, a day. Sometimes it's late, and then it's early and it's really exhausting.
How do you feel about having a job like this that long?
I think that a lot of work does help to get a little knowledge, but sometimes it's a little inefficient. Especially when I feel that I'm not what I expected, I feel more anxious and weak.
I understand how you feel. How do you feel when you see someone else that seems to be easy to accomplish?

Because I see people who can do it quickly and do it well. And I see them getting a lot of recognition and good grades in competitions or projects, and I feel a little bit less every time, which makes me feel bad.
These are really sad. Can you say in particular what way you think you're less than others?
For example, painting skills, creativity and detail. They can always catch something I don't think about, and their work is always recognized by teachers and judges, and I rarely have the chance.
It feels like you're having some frustration and confusion about painting.
Yeah, I'm a design major, and I've got a lot of drawing lessons. I've chosen this direction because of interest, but slowly I find myself less good than I thought.
Sounds like you're disappointed in your performance. How do teachers or classmates usually judge your abilities?

Sometimes teachers would say I'm solid, but more to me, and I hope I can improve. And the students would judge me less directly, more to us, to talk and point out, but sometimes to me, to feel they're secretly comparing me with other students.
Oh, I see.

So every time I hear a classmate or teacher say I'm not good, it's hard to know that it's good for me, but I feel bad for myself. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
You seem to be very concerned about the opinions and suggestions of others, but you're also stressed and troubled by them, aren't you?

Yes, I always feel that I never meet the expectations of others, or that I never do better than them, and I always fear being treated low or ignored. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.
Although teachers and students do not always assess your abilities directly, you still have little confidence in yourself.
It is. Every time I see everyone making progress, and I seem to be always on the ground, it's frustrating to me. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.
Well, you think people don't say it, but they still say it to you, do they?
Yeah, I think they're always comparing me to the others, and I'm not as good as the others. It's stressful, sometimes they don't even dare to show their work.
I understand that. What's your first reaction when you're being advised by your teacher?
I wonder if my work is really bad, so there's so much to improve. Sometimes I wonder if I'm wrong about the profession, not for that direction.
Well, I get it. Do you think the teacher's advice is to help you advance, or is it something else?
I think teachers might want me better, but sometimes I think he's not happy with me, and I think I'm not good enough or hard enough.

Understand your feelings. Sounds like you're more focused on your shortcomings when you get feedback from the teacher and you're getting some negative ideas, right? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yeah, that's always the way it is. Even if the teacher's feedback is objective, I'm going to automatically think of myself under the standards of other classmates.
From your description, it seems that the teacher's feedback to everyone is a few changes, is that it?
Yes, teachers do have opinions and suggestions for everyone, but I always feel that my advice is so much and that I look bad.
I understand. I get a lot of advice. Sometimes it makes people feel bad enough. How do you feel?
Maybe, I didn't ask them specifically, but every time they showed confidence, I thought they wouldn't have my problems.
It's easy to feel a little pressure when you see people showing confidence. You think they might not have problems like you, which makes you feel more different.
Yes, it is true that everyone has something that they're good at. It's just that I don't feel like I have a place to be, so it's hard to get a edge in competition.
Feels like you're not special, and it's really frustrating. So, what do you think you're good at?
Well, I think my painting is still solid and I know some basic techniques well. And there are times when my work is more detailed.
And these sound like very strong foundations and skills. So, do these parts make you feel confident or productive?
Maybe, but I don't feel special enough for myself.

I understand. Even though these strengths may not seem so special at this time, they are indeed part of your strengths and may help you in many ways. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yeah, maybe I always measure myself by someone else's standards, so I always feel bad enough. Sometimes I feel like I have to represent my community on campus, which adds stress.
You should be talking about your experience, but you have a lot of your own unique abilities and strengths. What do you think you're doing better?

Hi. I'm a Hispanic college student, and I wanted to talk about what's been weighing on me. Hello.
Hello, welcome. When did you start to get upset?
It started in May, when I was on diet to lose weight and then started eating.
Uh, I get it. Would you like to talk about this in detail? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yes, you can ask. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
Okay. How much do you usually eat when you're eating? Can you share a concrete example with me?
Sometimes they eat a lot, like a bag of chips, a box of pizza, a couple of bags of snacks and desserts, and they don't stop.
It sounds like you don't realize when you eat, you feel like you're eating mechanically, right?
Yeah, it's like automatic, unconsciously eating, completely unstoppable.
I see. It's really annoying. What kind of food do you usually eat?
It's mostly high-carbon water, like chips, cookies, cakes, chocolates.
I understand. It's hard for you to control, isn't it?
Yeah, you'll eat anything you see, and you'll eat it up and down. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
It sounds like you're feeling helpless and it's hard to stop even if you don't want to eat.
Uh, yeah.
It's understandable that it's not something you really want to eat, but it can't stop.
Yeah, I'm not really hungry, I can't control myself.
This has been going on for some time, remember?
It started in May, and it was controlled well before the diet, but then it went out of control.
Well, I see. You mentioned that you tried to adjust your diet by dieting, right?
Yeah, I tried to regulate it by some way, but it didn't work out very well. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
Well, what have you done?
I tried sports, especially dancing, meditation and reading, but these were only temporary reliefs and would return to that depression.
Sounds like you've tried a lot of ways. So dancing helps you? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yeah, I can forget some troubles while dancing, but it's not going to last long. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
I can feel your joy in dancing. Do you like dancing?
Yeah, I've been dancing since I was a kid, but now I'm losing that passion.
Uh, I'm listening. Why do you think the dance brings you joy is so short? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yeah, it's like it's just fun at the dance, and it's the same thing.
How do you usually feel when you finish dancing?
Yes, sometimes it feels even more empty and helpless than before.
When did this feel like it? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Well, it started about a few months ago, and it wasn't before.
Sounds like a surprise change to you.
Yes, I feel that I am becoming increasingly unable to control my emotions and behaviour, especially helpless.
I can understand why you feel helpless.
Yeah, it's hopeless.
Do you also feel anxious to get out of this situation? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
Yes, I really want to get out of this situation, but I don't know what to do.
Yeah, I get it. We'll talk later.
Okay, thank you for understanding.
I hope I can help you through this.
Thank you, really appreciate it.
You're welcome. I think we can try to figure out the challenges we're facing together. What do you think? One has been a low mood for some time, and the other is about diet.
Yes, depression is the main problem, and then the bulging of food bothers me. My family’s support matters a lot, but it can also come with expectations.
I understand that this is really disturbing. Do you feel that depression affects the efficiency of work and communication?
Yes, I find it difficult to concentrate when I work and rarely want to interact with colleagues.
Well, I understand. Do you think a low mood can cause diet problems?
Because every time I'm in a bad mood, I want to eat, like eating is the only thing that makes me happy for a short time.
Mm-hmm, I know.
But it makes you feel worse after eating and feels worse.

Yes, they are very cautious about money, but they are very expensive in school, like paying expensive remedial classes. But they never praise me for my slightly better grades, and they always feel that there is more room for improvement.

Yeah, they don't like to listen to me, they always think I'm a kid, they don't know anything. And they get angry at little things and they just put it on me.

Yes, I was filled with hope for the future and a desire for success. But now, it is becoming a burden and a pressure that makes me more and more unbearable. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”

Well, they're tough on themselves. Every time my parents talk about how they fought and how they achieved what they did, they're proud of themselves, but they want me to do better than they do.
Well, you can tell us separately what Mom and Dad are asking about themselves.

My dad was the kind of person who took responsibility for his work very seriously, and he'd always worked hard for his career, never allowed herself to be a little slack. And my mom, she always tried to be perfect between her family and her career, and everything was best.

He relaxes, for example, when he drinks, he gets drunk and then says things that he doesn't usually say. It actually makes me feel a little contradictory, because I can feel his insatiableness and stress on something.

Yeah, the more you try not to care, the easier you care. It's a common psychological phenomenon.

Hi. I'm a Hispanic college student, and I wanted to talk about what's been weighing on me. Hello, Tiny-Tian. My name is Ming. Yes, I do have a high demand for my studies and hope I can achieve good results. But I'm always very restless and unable to concentrate.
Well, what would it feel like to be depressed if we didn't reach that goal?
I feel anxious and lost, besides frustration. Sometimes I feel useless and never meet my expectations. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”

Well, you can feel your desire for and your questioning of this goal. Can you say in what circumstances you're going to feel this way? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.

This lag is mainly due to the fact that I see other students finishing their homework or getting good results from the exams, and I always feel that I can't learn and that I'm inefficient. They seem to be all easier and worse than I am.
Does it sound like you're feeling a little weak to see someone else do their homework easily, and you feel pressure? How does that pressure make you feel?
Yes, there is a certain disappointment. Especially when I see others making progress and I'm walking on the ground and even feeling a backlash, that sense of incompetence is stronger.
I feel you've been paying attention to your performance. How long has it been going on?

These emotions are going to be months. Every time you try to learn, you get frustrated because you can't concentrate, and then you start to blame yourself and feel that you're useless. As a Hispanic student, I sometimes feel pulled between school and family expectations.
Well, this self-pity seems to be in your state. Can you tell me what it's done to you?
Yes, this self-pity makes me less interested in learning, sometimes even avoiding it. For a long time, I find my learning less efficient and less focused.

Well, it's like a bit of a distraction and then you don't want to go to school. I feel like you're looking forward to learning and being passionate, just because you can't. It's hard to be disappointed with some of your efforts. You say you don't want to learn. What do you do at this time?

When I get upset, I try to do something else to distract attention, like watching movies, playing games or sleeping. But these are just temporary escapes, and it still feels hard to return to the desk.
It's been a tough time, isn't it? How did you deal with these bad emotions?

I don't dare talk to people about this, and I'm afraid they'll think I'm looking for excuses or I'm incompetent. Sometimes I'll talk to my family, but they'll always encourage me to find a way to overcome it.

I see you saying, "What's the situation after that?" You're saying, "What's the story?" Sounds like you've been learning, but these efforts don't seem to have produced the desired results. I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.

The result of forcing myself to learn is that it remains inefficient, feeling even more tired and frustrated. Yes, I always think I'm good, but I've been struggling, and that contrast often puts a lot of pressure on me.
Well, then what is the specific pressure you feel?

This image is like a student who learns well and does well, a “tough-down” who thinks he can do well without too much effort. But in fact, I spend a lot of time and energy, but I often do half the work.
It's hard to sound like you're carrying that image. Does this image of what you want to see be of particular importance to you? I also want to honor the cultural and family context you’re carrying.
I like math, but I've been having trouble with math lately. This good image of learning is a proof of myself, of being capable of being recognized and respected by others.
Um, I saw you say "disgrace," but can you tell me what happened? Have you ever seen anything like this?

Yes, sometimes the exam results are not ideal, and teachers and classmates look at me with the look of surprise or disappointment, and it really embarrasses me. After a few test failures, I'm a hard person, and I don't even look at people's eyes.
It sounds like it's hard for you to go through. How does that look like?
Yes, I care about the other people's comments. They certainly make me feel very successful, but their criticism or disappointments get me into self-skepticism and feel bad enough.
I see. You seem to value the assessment of others. What does it make you feel like when you get criticized or disappointed?
Maybe, but every time I see it, I feel consciously that my failures are magnified, and that others may not care that much, but it's a big blow to me.
Like when you're faced with a scene like this, it gets strong, right?

The love of all people makes me feel worthwhile and valuable, and it gives me comfort and confidence. Being bilingual, I notice I can express some feelings better in Spanish, but I’m trying in English here.
What are the main people you refer to, "all of them"?
It's mostly teachers, classmates and family members. Their identity is important to me, and I hope they can see my efforts and achievements.
I feel like maybe what you want most is a love for yourself. Do you think that's what it's like?
Perhaps what I need most is to learn to embrace myself, to recognize its efforts and values, rather than to rely too much on others' evaluations.

I feel your enthusiasm for learning and your high demands on yourself, which are remarkable things. I believe it's not just me, but many people feel it. I've heard you criticize yourself. Let's try to find out where we deserve to be.
Well, I will try to discover and acknowledge my strengths and efforts, which may help me alleviate some anxiety and self-pity.
It seems that we have hidden the middle ground from the result of a disappointment. The rest of our anger is proof of progress and progress, and behind these anxiety is proof of our serious life.

Yes, it may be because I care and expect so much. Maybe it's also a reminder that I'm serious about life and learning. I’m also thinking about finances and being first-gen—there’s pressure to “make it worth it.”
If you want, we can continue to discuss this issue at the next time.
Well, thank you very much, Tiny. I'll consider next time to continue consulting, hopefully, to improve my situation gradually.
Here are two questionnaires to help me get a better understanding and assessment of your current situation, and think you're offering more targeted counselling.
Okay, I'll take it seriously.
Thank you very much for your careful completion, which will be very helpful for us in our next consultation. You can tell me any questions or questions.
